timeline.bodyText: How does the ALL component only correspond to the hyperion enabled channel? Is there no separate enabled channel?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
According to Hyperion docs, sending on/off to special component "ALL":

saves/restores current state of every component,
toggles every component on/off,
effectively disabling/enabling hyperion.

Also I double checked by looking at their standalone app which comes with Hyperion:
$ hyperion-remote --help | grep -e Activate -e Deactivate
  --off                                              Deactivates hyperion
  --on                                               Activates hyperion

What this app do is actually calling API for component "ALL":
$ strace -s 9999 -f -e trace=network,write hyperion-remote --off -a 192.168.0.203:19444 
...
write(2, "Connected to: \"192.168.0.203:19444\"\n", 36Connected to: "192.168.0.203:19444"
...
write(2, "Disable Component \"ALL\"\n", 24Disable Component "ALL"
...
write(5, "{\"command\":\"componentstate\",\"componentstate\":{\"component\":\"ALL\",\"state\":false}}\n", 80) = 80
...

Basically, there is no dedicated disable/enable channel except API shorthand for disabling/enabling ALL components.
